refnamediv.refpurpose: Bind a feature to a model/archetype/personality

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The aq bind feature command governs when a given feature should be activated by binding a feature to various objects like model, archetype or personality. If the parameters of a host or interface match the binding parameters, then the feature is activated. If the binding specifies multiple matching criteria, then the host or interface must match all.

The same feature may be bound to multiple objects simultaneously (like both to the personality and the archetype of a host). Even if that's the case, the feature template will be included only once. The aq bind feature will also warn if you want to create a binding that is redundant.

listitem.para: The name of the feature to bind.
Name of a hardware model. If the model refers to a machine, then FEATURE must be a hardware feature. If the model refers to a network interface, then FEATURE must be an interface feature.
Binding a feature to a model globally is not allowed, you must also specify either --archetype or --personality.
Name of the vendor, if MODEL is not unique.
Name of a personality. FEATURE must be a host feature, unless --model or --interface is also specified, in which case the rules for the respective option apply.

Name of an archetype. If --personality is used, then this option is used as a qualifier to select the right archetype if the name of the personality is not unique. If this option is used without --personality, then it specifies the archetype to bind to.

Binding a feature to an archetype is subject to change management control and requires the use of option --justification. The only exception is when the archetype has no hosts (i.e. when it is still under development); in this case --justification is not needed.
Name of a network interface. FEATURE must be an interface feature, and it gets activated only for interfaces named IFACE.
It is not allowed to specify an archetype-wide interface binding, you must also specify option --personality.

Specifies the justification of the change. This option is required if the scope of the operation exceeds a personality (i.e. if you're modifying archetype bindings) or modifies a personality with production hosts.

The syntax of REASON is MANAGER=TICKET, where MANAGER is the change manager like tcm for TCM2, and TICKET is the ticket number (the TCM number when using TCM2) or the string "emergency" with --reason specified.
This string option needs to be specified to explain why the --justification=emergency was used.

example.title: Bind a host feature to an archetype
example.programlisting: aq bind feature --feature foo --archetype aquilon --justification tcm=600123456
example.para: After executing the above command, all Aquilon hosts will have the following line added to the host plenary template:
Note that modifying an archetype requires a valid TCM, and executing the above command can take a significant time.

example.title: Bind a hardware feature to a personality and model
example.programlisting: aq bind feature --feature foo --model dx320-6388ac1 --personality unixeng-test
example.para: After executing the above command, all dx320-6388ac1 hosts in the unixeng-test personality will have the following line added to the host plenary, just after the OS template:
Note that the presence of the --model means that foo is treated as a hardware feature.

example.title: Bind an interface feature to a personality
example.programlisting: aq bind feature --feature foo --personality unixeng-test --interface bond1
